text: Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So as you follow up with the lung doctors and then Dr. G__ and I just need to know who’s going to order the scans to say the Enzalutamide is not working anymore. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And we would keep you on it if we’re going to do the immuno-therapy study. We would stop it if we were going to go to chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and then the first-in-human study—I don’t know whether we have slots right now.

text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself? Patient: No. Um, none at this time. Doctor: Okay. So, what we’ll do is we’ll um we’ll be able to answer some questions over the phone when we call you as well in about a week. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Talk to you about the clinical trials. If you read through this and you say thanks but no thanks, that’s perfectly fine. I’m still going to be your doc and I’m still going to be your oncologist. Um and you have every right you know to turn this down if it’s not right for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But this a reasonable option that um if I was the patient, I would also consider. So I will leave that with you, put that underneath this one.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But some protocols do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So those are just nuance of that type of escalation. Uh. You --- it would be a window. So, it would be something that again if you’re trying to avoid chemotherapy, here’s something that I could try. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s, uh, uh, the third option of a trial, so, is chemotherapy plus vitamin C, a phase one study. The other study would be that we would have to check a blood test on you, uh, that if you came back as AR-V7 positive. And I’d have to see if we’ve already done that for you in the past. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Um, and you’ve had Enzalutamide, so I think you’d be good to go on that one. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are.

text: Patient: and the chemo. Doctor: the chemo and that’s a nationwide study so, you know, we would pretty much kind of consider that one for you. And then there’s another trial of just pills. You say, listen, Dr. H____ there’s no way your’e giving me any more chemo, get away from me, then there’s a study with two pills so the one pill that I would offer you and then another pill that is also FDA approved but you know in cancer it’s like hey, one’s good, let’s try two. So, the combo isn’t chemo plus pill, but it’s pill plus pill. How are we doing? Patient: I’m there. Doctor: Yeah, I can see it. It’s kind of a lot but the good news is there’s a lot of options and that’s me banking on everything as the worse-case scenario as, you know, you know, Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: that’s how I am because I don’t want you to fret that there’s nothing to do after we get the scans. We have tons of stuff to do. It’s just being thoughtful about what you want in terms of what’s the best thing. Questions? Patient: Not on that. I had one other. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I was just, is it part of the prostate that your bladder don’t empty all the way sometimes? Doctor: Sometimes. Is that acting up? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m worried about and we’ll certainly capture that when we do the scan. Um, are you just peeing like every hour or what’s going on? Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours.

text: Family Member: Oh! Doctor: So it wasn’t by choice. Healthcare Professional: What kind of car did you get? Family Member: Did you get your Caddy? Doctor: I did not. Doctor: Yeah, I didn’t want the big tank of a car. Family Member: No, so you have the car. Doctor: No, it’s not an SUV. I didn’t want the SUV.

text: Family Member: February fifth till – Doctor: Oh yeah, because even if you start in January, it’s monthly, so. Family Member: So February fifth till like the twenty, till like the twenty-second or something. Doctor: Oh that’s fine. That’s fine. Family Member: So we have to schedule that around then. Doctor: Oh yeah, he’ll, trust me, we will hunt you down. He will hunt you down because every time you’re about to get a dose, it’s fifteen thousand dollars a dose. Family Member: Oh my god! Doctor: When I say we got to get insurance right, we got to get insurance right. But we also, they don’t mix it; they don’t pop the tab unless you’re around because there’s no re-do. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
